conclusion: There are four objects (A, B, C, D) on the ground.
A light source is positioned above these objects, casting shadows on the ground.
The shadows (indicated by the red arrows) are cast in front of the objects, suggesting the light source is behind the objects.

premise: The light source moves forward, closer to the objects along the direction they are facing.

conclusion: When the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift to the back of the objects because the light rays now come from the front, casting the shadows behind.
The shadows will typically become smaller as the light source moves closer to the objects due to the angle of the light rays decreasing, resulting in shorter shadows.
In the key step illustration, the shadows are now shorter and cast behind the objects.

premise: The shadows are now shorter and cast behind the objects.
conclusion: When the light source moves forward, the shadows cast by objects A, B, C, and D will move to the back and become shorter.
